Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I had just moved into the new apartment complex, and I wanted to make a good impression. My mother always said that being a good neighbor meant being friendly and polite, so I baked a small cake to share with the people next door. As I was about to leave for my cousin’s upanayanam ceremony—a sacred thread ritual that my family had been planning for weeks—I saw Mrs. Sharma, my neighbor, coming up the stairs. She smiled warmly, and I realized this was the perfect moment to introduce myself and offer the cake. But I glanced at my watch; the ceremony was about to start, and I still needed to change into my kurta and get to the temple on time. I felt a knot in my stomach. If I stopped to chat and share the cake, I’d be late for the ceremony, disappointing my family and disrespecting the tradition. But if I rushed past Mrs. Sharma, I’d seem rude and unfriendly, failing as a good neighbor. I stood there, cake in hand, heart pounding, torn between two worlds that both mattered deeply to me.
